body:
Agreed, this is something I've never looked too carefully at, but I was aware there was some weirdness there.

I don't think those files are added to the classpath at all.  We could remove the mappings to include them, but I think some people depend on them being there and then they manually configure Play to point to them.  The option is to include that conf directory on the classpath (and ensure it's first on the classpath), which is probably not a bad idea, but it does change existing behaviour.

You can put it on the classpath in your build by doing something along the lines of this in `build.sbt`:

``` scala
import NativePackagerKeys._

scriptClasspath := "../conf" :+ scriptClasspath.value
```

One problem with the above, I'm not sure if it will work on Windows - the generated batch script will probably end up with the forward slash, not sure how the JDK on Windows copes with that.

issue.title: Add the tarball's /conf dir to the classpath
issue.body:
using the method suggested in https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/3473

I was mistaken in #52 - I thought the conf dir was on the classpath and being shadowed, but it wasn't on the classpath at all.

body:
This `conf` directory in the `dist` packaging is something that bit me, too.

As an indication that this thing bites others as well, here are some issues I think are somewhat related:
- #1079 and #1209 seem the be the cause of it.
- In #2084 it is actually called _expected behaviour_.
- I found some [StackOverflow Answers](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24375624/how-to-exclude-files-under-conf-folder-for-distribution/24380098#24380098) which actually want to remove it.
- #3472 is already mentioned by the author of this issue.
- ... there are likely more related issues which I haven't found yet

That is what I found after a quick search. The point I'm trying to make here is:
What might be _expected behaviour_ by the team doesn't seem to be expected by the users.

What is the purpose of the `dist` `app/conf` folder, if it is not loaded anyway?
Somewhere I read that you can refer to it by `-Dfile.config` and those files there are meant as _templates_. In this case I would vote for calling the directory `template` instead.

I would appreciate if we could somehow change the status quo and would propose to either remove the content or rename / move it somewhere where the purpose gets clearer.
What makes this worse is that the `conf` folder in `Dev` mode is actually the place to configure the application - so the developer are actually used to expect the contents of it to be configuration (not templates).

could not agree more with the troubles we had with this in prod. we find it very useful to change things like logger,  connection strings etc even if in production. otherwise what's the point of including the conf dir? please make conf folder operational so that we could alter it's content and restart to see the effect. this refers to both  regular conf files and logback configuration files!

issue.title: "dist" command crashes with "java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -2"

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
I'm developing a project with several subprojects.  The basic project organization is based on the Activator template at https://github.com/adrianhurt/play-multidomain-seed.

I just tried to do the "dist" command for the first time and received 

```
info] 
[info] Your package is ready in /Users/bwbecker/oat/src/oat3/modules/wapp/target/universal/oat3-wapp-3.0-SNAPSHOT.zip
[info] 
[info] 
[info] Your package is ready in /Users/bwbecker/oat/src/oat3/target/universal/oat3-3.0-SNAPSHOT.zip
[info] 
[trace] Stack trace suppressed: run last wsvc/universal:mappings for the full output.
[error] (wsvc/universal:mappings) java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -2
[error] Total time: 6 s, completed 17-Mar-2015 11:44:06 AM
```

Running "last wsvc/universal:mappings" yields

```
[oat3-wsvc] $ last wsvc/universal:mappings
java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -2
    at java.lang.String.substring(String.java:1875)
    at play.PlaySettings$$anonfun$defaultSettings$75$$anonfun$apply$5.apply(PlaySettings.scala:288)
    at play.PlaySettings$$anonfun$defaultSettings$75$$anonfun$apply$5.apply(PlaySettings.scala:287)
    at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
    at scala.collection.TraversableLike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(TraversableLike.scala:244)
    at scala.collection.mutable.ResizableArray$class.foreach(ResizableArray.scala:59)
    at scala.collection.mutable.ArrayBuffer.foreach(ArrayBuffer.scala:47)
    at scala.collection.TraversableLike$class.map(TraversableLike.scala:244)
```

Looking at the source to PlaySettings.scala, lines 283-290 are

``` scala
    mappings in Universal ++= {
      val confDirectoryLen = confDirectory.value.getCanonicalPath.length
      val pathFinder = confDirectory.value ** ("*" -- "routes")
      pathFinder.get map {
        confFile: File =>
          confFile -> ("conf/" + confFile.getCanonicalPath.substring(confDirectoryLen))
      }
    },
```

So it seems to be related to configuration files.  Some of my subproject config files are soft-linked.  The following set breaks:

```
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   290B  6 Mar 12:17 application.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    24B 17 Mar 12:06 local.conf -> ../../../conf/local.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   419B  6 Mar 12:17 prod.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    29B  6 Mar 12:17 shared.dev.conf -> ../../../conf/shared.dev.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    30B  6 Mar 12:17 shared.prod.conf -> ../../../conf/shared.prod.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   426B  6 Mar 12:17 wsvc.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   4.0K 17 Mar 09:45 wsvc.routes
```

while the following work (the only change is renaming local.conf to shared.local.conf.):

```
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   290B  6 Mar 12:17 application.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   419B  6 Mar 12:17 prod.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    29B  6 Mar 12:17 shared.dev.conf -> ../../../conf/shared.dev.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    31B 17 Mar 12:10 shared.local.conf -> ../../../conf/shared.local.conf
lrwxr-xr-x  1 bwbecker  staff    30B  6 Mar 12:17 shared.prod.conf -> ../../../conf/shared.prod.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   426B  6 Mar 12:17 wsvc.conf
-rw-r--r--  1 bwbecker  staff   4.0K 17 Mar 09:45 wsvc.routes
```

The full path for the above conf directory is `/Users/bwbecker/oat/src/oat3/modules/wsvc/conf/`

body:
The problem is that `conf` is being used by people for two different things. The first is that it's a resources directory that goes on your classpath like `src/main/resources` would in a typical project. The second is that some people want a place to put external configuration files that are included in a directory packaged with the app when you run `dist`. Right now the `conf` directory gets both included into your jar and then included again a second time in the dist zip. Having it in two places as we do now is a recipe for confusion. I know folks on my team have been caught off guard by this in the past and I needed to explain to them how it worked because it was causing trouble for them.

I personally think the best solution here would be to stop using this directory for two different things. I would create a new directory called `resources` that has the resources you want to be on your classpath and use `conf` just for the external configuration. This would have to be mentioned in the migration guide to make sure folks move files from `conf` to `resources` as needed.

If we split the current `conf` directory into two like this, then there's the question of where do you want `application.conf` to be located? You can put it in either place and it will work just fine. You just need to set the command line flag accordingly to load it either as a resource or a file. I believe more people would probably want it located externally.

issue.title: Sorted out conf directory

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
- conf directory in dist artifact is now added to the classpath by
  default
- Added externalizeResources SBT setting to turn off including the
  conf directory as an external (as in, not in the applications jar)
  directory and including it in the classpath
- Added --no-exit-sbt flag to Play start and stop commands to help with
  scripted tests
- Updated distribution scripted test, which now tests running Play in
  prod mode, as well as testing if the conf directory is on the
  classpath.

Fixes #3473.

Depends on #4108 being merged first.

issue.title: Dist on Windows packages files in conf folder incorrectly

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
File names under conf directory in the result .zip file start with '\'. As a result application fails to start.

Steps to reproduce: on dev machine (Windows 7) in play console run 'dist'
Copy zip file to target server (Linux). Run 'unzip xxx.zip', cd 'xxx/bin', ./xxx. Nothing happens and the application fails to start. 

That's how conf directory looks like:
[root@RH-ENGINE-QA]# ll conf
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1926 Nov 21 15:52 \application.conf
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  919 Dec 10 16:05 \ehcache.xml
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  305 Dec 15 11:50 \servers.xml
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  827 Dec 15 12:05 \trade-monitor-context.xml

After renaming files to be without leading '\', the startup succeeds.

Play version 2.2.1

issue.title: failed in windows 8

repository.name: JATOS
repository.description: Just Another Tool for Online Studies

issue.body:
I asked Fede to test JATOS in windows 8 (you met him in Argentina). He has windows 8 and is a programmer. 

He said:
-He downloaded jatos (version 1.1.8)
-Unizipped it (ok)
-Checked that production.conf was in the conf directory (ok)
-Double-clicked on loader.bat. Nothing happened. No console opened. He checked the loader.bat file and found nothing weird.
-He typed loader.bat start in the wondows console. He got the error mesage: Error: Could not find or load main class C:\proyectos\jatos-1.1.8-beta\lib\aopalliance.aopalliance-1.0.jar  
Although apparently the file IS in the lib folder
-then he checked the bat file, but found nothing weird. (he suggests we use two different bat files, one for start, one for stop.  i don't know whether this is relevant).
-The localhost:9000 doesn't open JATOS in the browser window 
-he's got jdk 7 installed. just in case this affects anything.. 

I wonder where we could get a windows 8 computer to test this...
